image.altText: A burnt out bike sits on the porch of a home destroyed by fire in Tara.

title.children: Tara blaze downgraded in Queensland as authorities gain the upper hand on grassfires outside Sydney

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Max Tillman It's been confirmed that a Tabulam home has been lost, in north-east of the state. The RFS added that two others have also been damaged. Spokesperson Greg Allan said that one property was destroyed in the Ogilvie Drive fire, but couldn't confirm exactly when it happened. There have also been reports of stock loss around Tenterfield and north-east NSW, he said. "Crews have been able to protect 15 properties within that area. "Our impact teams have been on the ground and will continue to do so over the coming days."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One home lost, two damaged in NSW

children.content: Reporting by Max Tillman
It's been confirmed that a Tabulam home has been lost, in north-east of the state.
The RFS added that two others have also been damaged.
Spokesperson Greg Allan said that one property was destroyed in the Ogilvie Drive fire, but couldn't confirm exactly when it happened.
There have also been reports of stock loss around Tenterfield and north-east NSW, he said.
"Crews have been able to protect 15 properties within that area.
"Our impact teams have been on the ground and will continue to do so over the coming days."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police are asking for information on "several suspicious fires" in Taree. A string of four fires this week kicked off about 6pm on Monday, with reports of a small bush fire on Hughes Street. Patrolling police then spotted a second fire at about 1.30am on Bushland Drive the next day. A third bushfire was located on the same stretch of road a short time later. Then, a fourth fire was noticed behind a property on Hughes Street just before 11.30pm on Tuesday. All four were extinguished by firefighters. Detectives from Manning and Great Lakes Police District believe the fires are suspicious and have commenced inquiries. Police are appealing anyone with info to contact Crime Stoppers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW Police say extinguished Taree fires are suspicious

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: QFES says residents of properties between Drildool Road, Crystal Creek Road, Tara Kogan Road, Upper Humbug Road and Wieambilla Road, including Chinchilla Tara Road, can return with caution. The fire is expected to keep burning for several days, but crews have ruled that it's safe enough for people to assess their properties. This fire has destroyed dozens of properties — many people will be seeing the damage first-hand for the first time.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tara fire now at advice level

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Simcha Greiniman is a volunteer driver for an Israeli group called ZAKA, which helps with body retrieval, and is often called to attend emergency scenes and provide immediate assistance. When he heard there had been a serious incident near the border with Gaza on October 7, he immediately jumped in his truck. He didn’t know what he was driving into when he headed down to southern Israel. Within hours of arriving, his truck was full with dozens of dead people who had been murdered by Hamas terrorists. Since then, he’s spent nearly every day collecting and transporting hundreds of bodies for identification and burial. He recounts one horrific story: “I walked into the house and there was a birthday cake sitting [there] … and you look up to the [photo on the] fridge and think, 'who had a birthday that day?'” he said. “We walk into the bedroom … and we see a family of five members, in a circle hugging each other. “You can’t believe what your eyes [have] seen, you cannot understand the situation. “One second there was a party and the next, death in the worst way you can think of.” Mr Greiniman said his team was still going through Kibbutzim near the border, searching for bodies and remains of people who had been killed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel's first responders recall the horror of what awaited them on October 7

children.content: Simcha Greiniman is a volunteer driver for an Israeli group called ZAKA, which helps with body retrieval, and is often called to attend emergency scenes and provide immediate assistance.
When he heard there had been a serious incident near the border with Gaza on October 7, he immediately jumped in his truck.

props.alt: A man stands next to an Israeli flag

children.content: Simcha volunteers for a search and rescue organisation called ZAKA.
(ABC News: Haidarr Jones)
He didn’t know what he was driving into when he headed down to southern Israel.
Within hours of arriving, his truck was full with dozens of dead people who had been murdered by Hamas terrorists.
Since then, he’s spent nearly every day collecting and transporting hundreds of bodies for identification and burial.
He recounts one horrific story:
“I walked into the house and there was a birthday cake sitting [there] … and you look up to the [photo on the] fridge and think, 'who had a birthday that day?'” he said.
“We walk into the bedroom … and we see a family of five members, in a circle hugging each other.
“You can’t believe what your eyes [have] seen, you cannot understand the situation.
“One second there was a party and the next, death in the worst way you can think of.”
Mr Greiniman said his team was still going through Kibbutzim near the border, searching for bodies and remains of people who had been killed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some Australians trapped in Gaza have been advised to go to the Rafah border crossing with Egypt amid reports it may open to some foreign nationals. An unknown number of Australians stuck in the besieged territory have been told that their names are "on the initial list of approved Australians" to cross into Egypt. The ABC has seen an email sent by Australian consular officials which says the border may open to some Australians at 9am local time (6pm AEDT) on Wednesday. The email urges recipients to "seize this opportunity to depart Gaza" if they "deem it safe to do so". Recipients have also been told to take enough food and water to last for at least five hours and expect large crowds. There are 88 Australian citizens, residents, and their families known to be in Gaza. International media have reported that Egypt is set to allow 400 foreign nationals to leave Gaza through its border after a deal was struck with the United States and Israel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some Australians in Gaza advised to go to Rafah crossing, in hopes it may open

featuredLink.title: 'Seize this opportunity': Australian families in Gaza told to head to Rafah border crossing

children.content: Some Australians trapped in Gaza have been advised to go to the Rafah border crossing with Egypt amid reports it may open to some foreign nationals.
An unknown number of Australians stuck in the besieged territory have been told that their names are "on the initial list of approved Australians" to cross into Egypt.
The ABC has seen an email sent by Australian consular officials which says the border may open to some Australians at 9am local time (6pm AEDT) on Wednesday.
The email urges recipients to "seize this opportunity to depart Gaza" if they "deem it safe to do so".
Recipients have also been told to take enough food and water to last for at least five hours and expect large crowds.
There are 88 Australian citizens, residents, and their families known to be in Gaza.
International media have reported that Egypt is set to allow 400 foreign nationals to leave Gaza through its border after a deal was struck with the United States and Israel.
